description: From Latin marsupium, marsuppium (“pouch, purse”), from Ancient Greek μαρσύπιον (marsúpion) or μαρσύππιον (marsúppion), variants of μαρσίππιον (marsíppion), diminutive of μάρσιππος (mársippos, “bag, pouch”); with English -al.

adjectives.description: marsupial (comparative more marsupial, superlative most marsupial)

entries.meaning: Of or pertaining to a marsupial.
examples: Showing that this animal is marsupial, consists of the following characters.

entries.meaning: (anatomy) Of or relating to a marsupium.

A mammal of which the female has a pouch in which it rears its young, which are born immature, through early infancy, such as kangaroos or koalas, or else pouchless members of the Marsupialia like shrew opossums.
